item.title: General Usage
item.description: WARNING Examples here are currently prone to rot. If something’s off, please submit a PR with updated content or an issue to notify me.

item.title: ARP Cache Poisoning
item.description: ARP Cache poisoning is a method for an attacker to establish an AITM position between an ARP sender and target.

item.title: ARP Cache
item.description: To minimize broadcast traffic, operating systems (OS) maintain a mapping of IPs to MACs in what’s known as an ARP cache.

item.title: ARP Payload
item.description: In ARP, Ethernet frames encapsulate the ARP payload containing the IP and MAC addresses of the sender and target.

item.title: ARP Reply
item.description: An ARP reply is sent in response to an ARP request. It replies to the sender with its MAC address.

item.title: ARP Request
item.description: An ARP request is sent by a sender when it needs to obtain the MAC address associated with an IP address.

item.title: ARP Sender
item.description: In ARP, the sender is the host that sent a given Ethernet frame containing an ARP payload, which always includes its IP and MAC addresses so that targets can manage caches and reply as needed.

item.title: ARP TLDR
item.description: Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) is a data link layer (OSI L2) protocol. ARP enables network communication by resolving IPs (L3) to MACs (L2).

item.title: ARP Target
item.description: In ARP, the target is the intended recipient of an Ethernet frame sent by a sender.
